title: How to correctly use 'what' and 'which' for non-native English speakers - Quora

response.answer_text: The general rule for using “What” and “which”, as I understand it easily, is; “What” is used when asking about an unknown number of things or choices. “What is that.” “I don’t know what to do.” “What do you want to do.” “Which” is used when the choices to select from are limited.” Which bird are you talking about.” “I was looking at my library to choose the book which I want to read again.” “Select the book on the shelf which you want to read next. “What” is used when you are clarifying the identity of the thing being discussed. “What is that object” “Which” is used to describe something that has already been identified. “Here is the object with the yellow ribbon, which is heavy”

“Which” is used when there is already a set of alternatives to choose from. “What” is used when the alternatives are unknown. I don’t know what to do. The possibilities are endless. I don’t know which tool to use. Only certain tools are available. I don’t know what tool to use. The tools are not limited to what’s at hand. How do you correctly use "what" and "which" for non-native English speakers?
